   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 86 year old female with a past medical history of occipital
   stroke with memory difficulties and atrial fibrillation who presents
   from home with cough for one week found in the emergency room to be
   hypotensive to the 80s sysotlic non-responsive to fluid challenge.
   Septic Shock:  Etiology unclear.  She was off pressors for 3.5 hours
   last night but put back on for SBP 60s.  ScVO2 was 65 and lactate is
   flat.  Random cortisol of 24.6 argues against adrenal insufficiency.
   At this time with hypotension, low grade fevers and tachycardia concern
   for sepsis although source is unclear.  [**Name2 (NI) **] CTA shows mild interstitial
   edema but no frank consolidations, urinalysis is negative, LFTs are
   unremarkable, blood cultures are pending.  History of cough, rhinorrhea
   and sore throat suggesting of a viral upper respiratory tract infection
   for which influenza would be in the differential.  Other considerations
   include hypotension secondary to dehydration in the setting of viral
   illness and diuretic use.  Cardiogenic shock is unlikely given lack of
   cardiac symptoms and normal EKG.  Currently with mildly decreased urine
   ouput, normal lactate, mild acute renal failure and confusion but
   unresponsive to fluid challenge and requiring levophed.
   - vancomycin, meropenem for empiric coverage of sepsis pending culture
   data
   - adding azithromycin for atypical PNA coverage
   - follow blood cultures
   - CVP goal [**7-18**] (given flash pul edema after 500cc x2 fluid boluses
   last night)
   - continue levophed as needed to maintain SBP> 90, UOP > 30 cc/hr; wean
   as tolerated
   - place arterial line today to better monitor BPs
   - f/u influenza swab
   - will hold metoprolol and bumetanide
   Hypoxia:  Patient with persistent oxygen requirement since her recent
   hospitalization despite no known primary lung disease.  On presentation
   she was 91% on 2L and since fluid resuscitation has required 3-4L with
   saturations in the high 90s.  Evidence of mild interstial edema on exam
   but does not appear significant enough to account for oxygen
   requirement. No evidence of pulmonary embolism on CTA.  No signs of
   hypercarbia on VBG.  Likely worse hypoxia after flash pulmonary edema
   earlier this morning.
   - holding home diuretics given hypotension
   - monitor for signs of volume overload
   - f/u influenza swab
   - outpatient pulmonary function tests
   - consider ABG to assess A-A gradient
   - albuterol PRN given expiratory wheezes
   Anemia:  Known iron deficiency anemia with baseline hematocrit 30.  Hct
   drop from 31.2 to 26.6 last night.
   - active type and screen
   - guaiac stools
   - transfuse 1 unit of pRBCs to improve hypotension
   - trend hematocrit
   - continue iron supplements
   Confusion:  Patient with waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 533**] mental status at home.
   Current exam consistent for delerium with primary aspect of
   disorientation with non-focal neurologic exam.  Patient with known
   occipital infarctions thought to be secondary to cardioembolic
   phenomenon.
   - continue home zyprexa and sertraline
   - evaluate for infection as above
   - monitor mental status
   - frequent orientation
   - optimize sleep wake cycle
   - limit medications that affect mental status as much as possible
   Atrial Fibrillation:  Rhythm currently in atrial fibrillation in the
   110s.  No chest pain or shortness of breath.
   - continue digoxin but will need to discontinue if renal failure
   worsens
   - holding metoprolol
   - on plavix as her antiplatelet [**Doctor Last Name **], unclear why not on aspirin
   - not on anticoagulation given bleeding risk
   Acute Renal Failure:  Improving.  Likely prerenal in the setting of
   what appears to be septic shock.
   - monitor  urine ouput and creatinine
   - renally dose medications
   Diastolic Heart Failure: Patient diagnosed with acute on chronic
   diastolic heart failure during recent hospitalization although her
   response to diuretics was unclear and she does not have a history of
   hypotension.  Echocardiogram with preserved ejection fraction.  She is
   on bumetanide as an outpatient.
   - hold diuretics
   - hold metoprolol
   Right lower extremity edema:  Unclear if this is a new finding.
   - R lower extremity ultrasound today
   Cerebrovascular Disease:  s/p occipital stroke in [**2200-6-9**] thought to
   be secondary to cardioembolic disease.
   - continue plavix
   - continue high dose statin
   - monitor neurologic exam
   FEN: Careful use of IVF for CVP < [**7-18**], UOP < 30 cc/hr, SBP < 90,
   replete electrolytes, regular diet
   Prophylaxis: Subutaneous heparin, famotidine
   Access: peripherals, RIJ
   Code:  DNR/DNI (discussed with niece)
   Communication: Patient, neice [**Name (NI) 322**] [**Name (NI) 885**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8206**]
   Disposition: ICU care for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Comments: Regular diet
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Presep Catheter - [**2200-8-29**] 08:13 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SQ UF Heparin(Systemic anticoagulation: None)
   Stress ulcer: H2 blocker
   VAP:  n/a
   Comments:
   Communication: Patient discussed on interdisciplinary rounds , Family
   meeting held , ICU consent signed Comments:
   Code status: DNR / DNI
   Disposition: ICU

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 86-year-old female with a past medical history of occipital stroke, atrial fibrillation, and iron deficiency anemia. She was admitted to the ICU with hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea, and was diagnosed with septic shock. The etiology of sepsis is unclear, but the patient has a history of cough, rhinorrhea, and sore throat, suggesting a viral upper respiratory tract infection. 

The patient has been treated with empiric antibiotics and antivirals, and is being closely monitored for signs of infection. She has also been started on vasopressors to maintain blood pressure, and is being treated for hypoxia with oxygen therapy.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction: The patient's septic shock could lead to organ dysfunction, such as acute kidney injury, liver dysfunction, or respiratory failure.

2. Pulmonary edema: The patient's pulmonary edema could worsen, leading to respiratory failure.

3. Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation could worsen, leading to cardiac complications such as heart failure or stroke.

4. Renal failure: The patient's acute kidney injury could worsen, leading to chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease.

5. Infection-related complications: The patient's sepsis could lead to complications such as pneumonia, urinary tract infection, or central line-associated bloodstream infection.

6. Hypoxia-related complications: The patient's hypoxia could worsen, leading to respiratory failure or cardiac complications.

7. Anemia-related complications: The patient's anemia could worsen, leading to fatigue, weakness, or shortness of breath.

8. Confusion-related complications: The patient's confusion could worsen, leading to delirium or dementia.

9. Right lower extremity edema-related complications: The patient's right lower extremity edema could worsen, leading to complications such as deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism.

10. Cerebrovascular disease-related complications: The patient's cerebrovascular disease could worsen, leading to stroke or transient ischemic attack.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent these complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 86 year old female with a past medical history of occipital
   stroke with memory difficulties and atrial fibrillation who presents
   from home with cough for one week found in the emergency room to be
   hypotensive to the 80s sysotlic non-responsive to fluid challenge.
   Septic Shock:  Etiology unclear.  At this time with hypotension, low
   grade fevers and tachycardia concern for sepsis although source is
   unclear.  [**Name2 (NI) **] CTA shows mild interstitial edema but no frank
   consolidations, urinalysis is negative, LFTs are unremarkable, blood
   cultures are pending.  History of cough, rinorrhea and sore throat
   suggesting of a viral upper respiratory tract infection for which
   influenza would be in the differential.  Other considerations include
   hypotension secondary to dehydration in the setting of viral illness
   and diuretic use.  Cardiogenic shock is unlikely given lack of cardiac
   symptoms.  Currently with mildly decreased urine ouput, normal lactate,
   mild acute renal failure and confusion but unresponsive to fluid
   challenge and requiring levophed.
   - vancomycin, meropenem for empiric coverage of sepsis pending culture
   data
   - follow blood cultures
   - will check CVP and consider additional fluid challenge if < [**10-20**]
   - will check ScVO2
   - continue levophed as needed to maintain MAP > 60, UOP > 30 cc/hr
   - will place arterial line if unable to quickly wean pressors
   - will check influenza swab given respiratory symptoms
   - will check random cortisol to assess for absolute adrenal
   insufficiency
   - will monitor lactate, urine output, CVP, ScVO2 and pressor
   requirement
   - will hold metoprolol and bumetanide
   Hypoxia:  Patient with persistent oxygen requirement since her recent
   hospitalization despite no known primary lung disease.  On presentation
   she was 91% on 2L and since fluid resuscitation has required 3-4L with
   saturations in the high 90s.  Evidence of mild interstial edema on exam
   but does not appear significant enough to account for oxygen
   requirement. No evidence of pulmonary embolism on CTA.
   - holding home diuretics given hypotension
   - monitor for signs of volume overload
   - check CVP now with goal [**10-20**] for resuscitation
   - influenza swab given symptoms
   - outpatient pulmonary function tests
   - VBG to assess for hypercarbia
   - consider ABG to assess A-A gradient
   - albuterol PRN given scarce expiratory wheezes
   Confusion:  Patient with waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 533**] mental status at home.
   Current exam consistent for delerium with primary aspect of
   disorientation with non-focal neurologic exam.  Patient with known
   occipital infarctions thought to be secondary to cardioembolic
   phenomenon.
   - continue home zyprexa and sertraline
   - evaluate for infection as above
   - monitor mental status
   - frequent orientation
   - optimize sleep wake cycle
   - out of bed to chair in AM
   - limit medications that affect mental status as much as possible
   Atrial Fibrillation:  Rhythm currently in atrial fibrillation in the
   110s.  No chest pain or shortness of breath.
   - continue digoxin but will need to discontinue if renal failure
   worsens
   - holding metoprolol
   - on plavix as her antiplatelet [**Doctor Last Name **], unclear why not on aspirin
   - not on anticoagulation
   Acute Renal Failure:  Likely prerenal in the setting of what appears to
   be septic shock.
   - monitor  urine ouput and creatinine
   - renally dose medications
   Hematocrit:  Known iron deficiency anemia.  Baseline hematocrit 30.  At
   her baseline.
   - active type and screen
   - trend hematocrit
   - continue iron supplements
   Diastolic Heart Failure: Patient diagnosed with acute on chronic
   diastolic heart failure during recent hospitalization although her
   response to diuretics was unclear and she does not have a history of
   hypotension.  Echocardiogram with preserved ejection fraction.  She is
   on bumetanide as an outpatient.
   - hold diuretics

   Right lower extremity edema:  Unclear if this is a new finding.

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old female with a past medical history of occipital stroke, memory difficulties, and atrial fibrillation. She was admitted to the ICU with septic shock, hypotension, and tachycardia, with unclear etiology. She has been treated with vancomycin and meropenem for empiric coverage of sepsis, and is being closely monitored for signs of infection, sepsis, and organ dysfunction.

The patient has a complex medical history, including atrial fibrillation, diastolic heart failure, and cerebrovascular disease. She is being treated with a variety of medications, including digoxin, plavix, and bumetanide, and is being monitored for signs of volume overload, hypoxia, and confusion.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for further deterioration due to sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction, respiratory failure, and death.
2. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's atrial fibrillation and diastolic heart failure increase her risk for cardiogenic shock, which can be life-threatening.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's septic shock and hypotension increase her risk for acute kidney injury, which can lead to chronic kidney disease and end-stage renal disease.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxia and respiratory symptoms increase her risk for respiratory failure, which can be life-threatening.
5. Confusion: The patient's confusion and disorientation increase her risk for falls, aspiration, and other complications.
6. Cerebral edema: The patient's history of cerebrovascular disease and current sepsis increase her risk for cerebral edema, which can lead to brain herniation and death.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies for signs of sepsis, organ dysfunction, and other complications.
2. Adjust the patient's medications and treatment plan as necessary to manage her symptoms and prevent further complications.
3. Consider additional testing, such as a head CT or MRI, to evaluate the patient's cerebrovascular disease and potential cerebral edema.
4. Provide supportive care, such as oxygen therapy and pain management, to help manage the patient's symptoms and improve her comfort.
5. Consider consulting with a cardiologist and/or nephrologist to further evaluate and manage the patient's cardiovascular and renal status.

   - will hold metoprolol and bumetanide
   Hypoxia:  Patient with persistent oxygen requirement since her recent
   hospitalization despite no known primary lung disease.  On presentation
   she was 91% on 2L and since fluid resuscitation has required 3-4L with
   saturations in the high 90s.  Evidence of mild interstial edema on exam
   but does not appear significant enough to account for oxygen
   requirement. No evidence of pulmonary embolism on CTA.
   - holding home diuretics given hypotension
   - monitor for signs of volume overload
   - check CVP now with goal [**10-20**] for resuscitation
   - influenza swab given symptoms
   - outpatient pulmonary function tests
   - VBG to assess for hypercarbia
   - consider ABG to assess A-A gradient
   - albuterol PRN given scarce expiratory wheezes
   Confusion:  Patient with waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 533**] mental status at home.
   Current exam consistent for delerium with primary aspect of
   disorientation with non-focal neurologic exam.  Patient with known
   occipital infarctions thought to be secondary to cardioembolic
   phenomenon.
   - continue home zyprexa and sertraline
   - evaluate for infection as above
   - monitor mental status
   - frequent orientation
   - optimize sleep wake cycle
   - out of bed to chair in AM
   - limit medications that affect mental status as much as possible
   Atrial Fibrillation:  Rhythm currently in atrial fibrillation in the
   110s.  No chest pain or shortness of breath.
   - continue digoxin but will need to discontinue if renal failure
   worsens
   - holding metoprolol
   - on plavix as her antiplatelet [**Doctor Last Name **], unclear why not on aspirin
   - not on anticoagulation
   Acute Renal Failure:  Likely prerenal in the setting of what appears to
   be septic shock.
   - monitor  urine ouput and creatinine
   - renally dose medications
   Hematocrit:  Known iron deficiency anemia.  Baseline hematocrit 30.  At
   her baseline.
   - active type and screen
   - trend hematocrit
   - continue iron supplements
   Diastolic Heart Failure: Patient diagnosed with acute on chronic
   diastolic heart failure during recent hospitalization although her
   response to diuretics was unclear and she does not have a history of
   hypotension.  Echocardiogram with preserved ejection fraction.  She is
   on bumetanide as an outpatient.
   - hold diuretics
   - hold metoprolol
   Right lower extremity edema:  Unclear if this is a new finding.
   - R lower extremity ultrasound in AM
   Cerebrovascular Disease:  s/p occipital stroke in [**2200-6-9**] thought to
   be secondary to cardioembolic disease.
   - continue plavix
   - continue high dose statin
   - monitor neurologic exam
   FEN: IVF for CVP < [**10-20**], UOP < 30 cc/hr, MAP < 60, replete
   electrolytes, regular diet
   Prophylaxis: Subutaneous heparin, famotidine
   Access: peripherals
   Code:  DNR/DNI (discussed with niece)
   Communication: Patient, neice [**Name (NI) 322**] [**Name (NI) 885**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8206**]
   Disposition: ICU care for now
   ICU Care

   Comments: Regular diet

   VAP:  n/a

   Communication: Patient discussed on interdisciplinary rounds , Family
   meeting held , ICU consent signed Comments:

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old female with a past medical history of occipital stroke, memory difficulties, and atrial fibrillation, who presents with cough, hypotension, and septic shock of unclear etiology. She has been treated with empiric antibiotics and is currently receiving levophed to maintain blood pressure. The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, diastolic heart failure, and cerebrovascular disease, and is currently experiencing acute renal failure, confusion, and hypoxia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock of unclear etiology may lead to further complications such as organ dysfunction, including renal, hepatic, and cardiovascular systems.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen, leading to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and anemia.
3. Confusion: The patient's confusion may progress, leading to increased risk of falls, aspiration, and other complications.
4. Hypoxia: The patient's hypoxia may worsen, leading to respiratory failure and increased risk of pneumonia.
5. Cardiac Complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and diastolic heart failure may lead to further cardiac complications, including cardiogenic shock and cardiac arrest.
6. Infection: The patient's septic shock may lead to further infections, including pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and bloodstream infections.
7. Fluid Overload: The patient's fluid resuscitation may lead to fluid overload, which may exacerbate her hypotension, cardiac dysfunction, and respiratory failure.
8. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's septic shock may lead to gastrointestinal complications, including nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.
9. Neurological Complications: The patient's cerebrovascular disease and septic shock may lead to further neurological complications, including stroke, seizures, and cognitive decline.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Chief Complaint:
   HPI:
   86 yo F admitted for dyspnea, cough, pink sputum. In rehab until 2
   weeks ago, came home with ?URI symptoms, neice who lives with her also
   became ill with similar symptoms. Hypotensive in ED to 70's, 2L IVF, no
   response, on levophed, CVL placed. On home O2 for unclear reasons; was
   started on diuretics for ?CHF on last admission.
   Overnight, UOP was low, 1L without change. CXR showed minimal volume
   overload, and with this bolus, she flashed, tachypneic to 40's. Lasix
   20mg, then 40mg, morphine, ativan, was able to be weaned off levophed,
   briefly in this setting. Breathing improved, then needed to be
   restarted on levophed.
   Currently on 4L by nasal cannula. Kept on vanco/[**Last Name (un) 614**] here overnight.

   Assessment and Plan
   86 yo F with hypoxic respiratory distress and hypotension.
 HYPOXEMIA - on home O2 at 2L unclear reasons. Diffuse ground glass
   opacities could represent infectious etiologies such as viral or
   atypical infection, noninfectious etiologies include hypersensitivity
   pneumonitis, new interstitial lung ds
 less likely. There is also
   evidence of acute decompensated heart failure - TTE with normal LVEF,
   likely acute on chronic diastolic dysfunction in the setting of volume
   overload and 2+MR, exacerbated by tachycardia when patient becomes
   agitated.
   Try to wean O2; lasix prn and caution with IVF
   PFT's as outpatient
   Follow up CT scan in several weeks to evaluate for
   resolution/progression
 HYPOTENSION
 on levophed at this time. Difficult to volume
   resuscitate given propensity for flash pulmonary edema. No clear source
   at this time, could be septic shock - patient's prodrome seems
   consistent with viral etiology vs. atypical bacteria. Lactate wnl.
   Cardiogenic shock should be considered given rapid heart failure onset,
   but cardiac enzymes in ED were negative. Also could be not associated
   with infectious etiology at all- could be secondary to blood loss (hct
   drop), hypovolemia, neurogenic (but unlikely).
   vanco, [**Last Name (un) 614**] for empiric coverage - adding back azithro for atypical
   coverage
   monitor cultures
 adding on legionella
   central venous sat 65
 can give blood slowly
   CVP - [**7-18**]
   guaiac stools
   holding diuretics unless acutely short of breath
   aline to be placed
   Anemia - likely has an iron deficiency anemia, but now has acute drop -
   no clear sign of bleed - guaiac stools
   Confusion - attributed on last admission to occipital strokes, could be
   worse in the setting of acute illness
   Afib - new as of last admission, but caution with rate control given
   hypotension; continue dig
   ARF - resolving, likely prerenal azotemia
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Comments: Regular
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Presep Catheter - [**2200-8-29**] 08:13 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: H2 blocker
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication: ICU consent signed Comments:
   Code status: DNR (do not resuscitate)
   Disposition :ICU
   Total time spent: 35 minutes
   Patient is critically ill

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU for hypoxic respiratory distress and hypotension. She has a history of rehabilitation and was started on home oxygen therapy for unclear reasons. She developed hypotension in the emergency department and was treated with vasopressors and diuretics. Her current condition is characterized by diffuse ground glass opacities on CT scan, which could represent infectious or non-infectious etiologies. She also has evidence of acute decompensated heart failure, likely due to acute on chronic diastolic dysfunction.

The patient's lab results show normal white blood cell count, platelet count, and hemoglobin level, but elevated lactate levels. Her electrocardiogram shows sinus rhythm, and her blood pressure is 86/54 mmHg.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's diffuse ground glass opacities on CT scan could lead to respiratory failure if not managed properly.
2. Sepsis: The patient's hypotension and elevated lactate levels could be indicative of sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Cardiac failure: The patient's acute decompensated heart failure could lead to cardiogenic shock, which could be life-threatening.
4. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is low, which could be due to iron deficiency anemia or acute blood loss.
5. Confusion: The patient's confusion could be attributed to her underlying medical conditions or the use of sedatives and analgesics.
6. Arrhythmias: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation could lead to arrhythmias, which could be life-threatening.
7. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels could indicate acute kidney injury, which could be due to prerenal azotemia or acute tubular necrosis.

ICU care plan:

1. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and provide oxygen therapy as needed.
2. Continue vasopressors and diuretics as needed to manage the patient's hypotension and fluid overload.
3. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely and provide cardiotonic medications as needed.
4. Monitor the patient's anemia and provide iron supplementation as needed.
5. Monitor the patient's confusion and provide sedatives and analgesics as needed.
6. Monitor the patient's arrhythmias and provide anti-arrhythmic medications as needed.
7. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and provide dialysis as needed.

 HYPOXEMIA - on home O2 at 2L unclear reasons. Diffuse ground glass
   opacities could represent infectious etiologies such as viral or
   atypical infection, noninfectious etiologies include hypersensitivity
   pneumonitis, new interstitial lung ds
 less likely. There is also
   evidence of acute decompensated heart failure - TTE with normal LVEF,
   likely acute on chronic diastolic dysfunction in the setting of volume
   overload and 2+MR, exacerbated by tachycardia when patient becomes
   agitated.
   Try to wean O2; lasix prn and caution with IVF
   PFT's as outpatient
   Follow up CT scan in several weeks to evaluate for
   resolution/progression
 HYPOTENSION (NOT SHOCK)
 on levophed at this time. Difficult to
   volume resuscitate given propensity for flash pulmonary edema. No clear
   source at this time, could be septic shock - patient's prodrome seems
   consistent with viral etiology vs. atypical bacteria. Lactate wnl.
   Cardiogenic shock should be considered given rapid heart failure onset,
   but cardiac enzymes in ED were negative. Also could be not associated
   with infectious etiology at all- could be secondary to blood loss (hct
   drop), hypovolemia, neurogenic (but unlikely).
   vanco, [**Last Name (un) 614**] for empiric coverage - adding back azithro for atypical
   coverage
   monitor cultures
 adding on legionella
   central venous sat 65
 can give blood slowly
   CVP - [**7-18**]
   guaiac stools
   holding diuretics unless acutely short of breath
   aline to be placed
   Anemia - likely has an iron deficiency anemia, but now has acute drop -
   no clear sign of bleed - guaiac stools
   Confusion - attributed on last admission to occipital strokes, could be
   worse in the setting of acute illness
   Afib - new as of last admission, but caution with rate control given
   hypotension; continue dig
   ARF - resolving, likely prerenal azotemia
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Comments: Regular
   Glycemic Control:

   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: H2 blocker
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication: ICU consent signed Comments:
   Code status: DNR (do not resuscitate)

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old female admitted to the ICU for dyspnea, cough, and pink sputum. She has a history of URI symptoms and was recently discharged from rehab. She is hypotensive and has been receiving levophed support. Overnight, her UOP was low, and she flashed with tachypnea, requiring boluses of Lasix and morphine. She is currently on 4L of oxygen via nasal cannula and has been started on vancomycin for empiric coverage.

The patient has a complex set of conditions, including:

1. Hypoxemic respiratory distress: The patient has been on home oxygen at 2L, but the reason is unclear. She has diffuse ground glass opacities on CTA, which could represent infectious or non-infectious etiologies.
2. Acute decompensated heart failure: The patient has evidence of acute decompensated heart failure, likely due to acute on chronic diastolic dysfunction, exacerbated by tachycardia.
3. Hypotension: The patient is hypotensive and has been receiving levophed support. The cause of her hypotension is unclear, but could be due to septic shock, cardiogenic shock, or hypovolemia.
4. Confusion: The patient has a history of confusion, which may be attributed to occipital strokes or worsened by her acute illness.
5. Anemia: The patient has an anemia, likely due to iron deficiency anemia, but with an acute drop in Hct.
6. Atrial fibrillation: The patient has new-onset atrial fibrillation, which may require rate control.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic respiratory distress and acute decompensated heart failure may lead to respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac arrest: The patient's hypotension and acute decompensated heart failure may lead to cardiac arrest.
3. Sepsis: The patient's hypotension and diffuse ground glass opacities on CTA may indicate sepsis.
4. Renal failure: The patient's acute kidney injury may progress to renal failure.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's anemia and guaiac stools may indicate gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's confusion and history of strokes may worsen in the setting of acute illness.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's oxygen saturation and adjust oxygen therapy as needed.
2. Continue to manage the patient's hypotension with levophed support and monitor for signs of shock.
3. Monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust rate control as needed.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust diuretic therapy as needed.
5. Monitor the patient's anemia and adjust iron therapy as needed.
6. Consider prophylactic antibiotics for the patient's respiratory viral screen.
7. Consider further imaging studies, such as a CT scan, to evaluate for resolution or progression of the patient's lung disease.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust therapy as needed.

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old female admitted to the ICU for dyspnea, cough, and pink sputum. She has a history of rehabilitation and was recently discharged, but returned with URI symptoms, including hypotension. She was started on oxygen therapy and diuretics for possible CHF. Overnight, she experienced low urine output, and her CXR showed minimal volume overload. She was treated with Lasix, morphine, and ativan, and was able to be weaned off levophed, but required restarting due to increased respiratory distress.

The patient is currently on 4L nasal cannula oxygen and has a central venous saturation of 65%. She has a history of anemia, confusion, and atrial fibrillation, and is being treated for ARF. She is also receiving prophylactic heparin and stress ulcer medication.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's oxygen requirements are increasing, and she may be at risk for respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's hypotension and diffuse ground glass opacities on CT scan may indicate a septic process.
3. Cardiac failure: The patient's rapid onset of heart failure and negative cardiac enzymes may indicate cardiogenic shock.
4. Bleeding: The patient's drop in Hct and guaiac stools may indicate bleeding, which could be secondary to anticoagulation therapy or other causes.
5. Renal failure: The patient's ARF may worsen if not managed appropriately.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's confusion and atrial fibrillation may worsen in the setting of acute illness.
7. Infection: The patient's respiratory viral screen and blood cultures are pending, and she may be at risk for infection.
8. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's stress ulcer prophylaxis and possible bleeding may indicate gastrointestinal complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 86-year-old female admitted to the ICU with dyspnea, cough, and pink sputum. She has a history of rehabilitation and was recently discharged, but returned home with symptoms similar to her niece who lives with her. The patient is currently receiving oxygen therapy, diuretics, and has a central venous catheter placed. 

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 38.1C (100.5F)
* Heart rate: 87 bpm
* Blood pressure: 86/54 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 22 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 98%
* Central venous pressure: 10 mmHg

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* General appearance: No acute distress
* Cardiovascular: S1 and S2 heart sounds normal, S3 present, systolic murmur
* Respiratory: Symmetric expansion, no dullness, crackles up to scapulae, wheezes on right side, diminished breath sounds overall
* Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, bowel sounds present
* Extremities: Right lower extremity edema 1+, left lower extremity edema 1+, no cyanosis, no clubbing
* Skin: Not assessed
* Neurologic: Responds to verbal stimuli, no movement, tone, or reflexes assessed

Laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 8.9 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 13.6 K/uL
* Platelet count: 245 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.0 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 14 mg/dL
* Glucose: 133 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.4 mmol/L
* Calcium: 7.5 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.6 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.9 mg/dL

Imaging studies reveal:

* Admission CXR: Possible mild volume overload, no obvious consolidative process
* CTA: Diffuse ground glass opacities, tiny right-sided pleural effusion
* Overnight CXR: Bilateral pulmonary edema

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Hypoxemia: Patient is on home oxygen therapy at 2L, unclear reasons. Diffuse ground glass opacities may represent infectious or non-infectious etiologies.
* Hypotension: No clear source at this time, could be septic shock, cardiogenic shock, or hypovolemic shock.
* Anemia: Likely has iron deficiency anemia, but now has acute drop, no clear sign of bleed.
* Confusion: Attributed to occipital strokes on last admission, could be worse in setting of acute illness.
* Afib: New as of last admission, but caution with rate control given hypotension.
* ARF: Resolving, likely prerenal azotemia.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure due to bilateral pulmonary edema and diffuse ground glass opacities
* Sepsis or septic shock due to possible infectious etiology
* Cardiogenic shock or hypovolemic shock due to acute heart failure or blood loss
* Anemia exacerbation due to ongoing bleeding or acute blood loss
* Confusion and disorientation due to underlying neurological conditions or acute illness
* Atrial fibrillation exacerbation due to hypotension or acute illness
* Acute kidney injury or acute respiratory distress syndrome due to underlying conditions or acute illness.

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old female with a past medical history of occipital stroke, memory difficulties, and atrial fibrillation. She was admitted to the ICU with hypotension, tachycardia, and altered mental status. The patient has a positive C. difficile (C. diff) culture, but the etiology of septic shock is unclear. She has a history of rhinorrhea, sore throat, and ground glass opacities, which may suggest a viral upper respiratory tract infection. The patient has been off pressors since 2 PM yesterday, and her cortisol level is within normal range, arguing against adrenal insufficiency.

The patient has the following conditions:

1. Septic Shock: The patient has septic shock, but the source of infection is unclear. C. diff is positive, but it does not explain the CT chest findings of ground glass opacities.
2. Hypoxia: The patient has persistent oxygen requirement, which may be due to cardiogenic causes, such as moderate aortic stenosis, or due to other causes such as influenza, PCP, or ARDS secondary to sepsis.
3. Anemia: The patient has known iron deficiency anemia, and her hematocrit is 24.6 today.
4. Confusion: The patient has waxing and waning mental status, which may be due to delirium or other causes.
5. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's rhythm is currently in atrial fibrillation, which is controlled with diltiazem and metoprolol.
6. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure, which is likely prerenal in the setting of septic shock and low urine output.
7. Diastolic Heart Failure: The patient has acute on chronic diastolic heart failure, which is not responding well to diuretics.
8. Right Lower Extremity Edema: The patient has right lower extremity edema, which may be due to DVT or other causes.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient has septic shock, which can lead to multiple organ dysfunction and death.
2. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient's hypoxia may be due to ARDS, which can lead to respiratory failure.
3. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's atrial fibrillation and diastolic heart failure increase the risk of cardiac arrest.
4. Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure may progress to chronic renal failure if not managed properly.
5. Infection: The patient's C. diff infection may spread to other parts of the body, leading to sepsis and multi-organ dysfunction.
6. Pulmonary Embolism: The patient's right lower extremity edema may be due to DVT, which can lead to pulmonary embolism and death.
7. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's anemia may be due to gastrointestinal bleeding, which can lead to further complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics for C. diff infection.
2. Monitor for signs of volume overload and adjust IVF fluid management accordingly.
3. Trend hematocrit and consider transfusing 1 unit of pRBCs to improve hypotension and anemia.
4. Increase iron supplements to [**Hospital1 7**].
5. Continue digoxin and f/u digoxin levels this AM.
6. Discontinue metoprolol and transition to PO diltiazem TID.
7. Monitor urine output and creatinine, and consider renally dosing medications.
8. Check urine sediment and UA to monitor for signs of ATN.
9. Hold diuretics and metoprolol.
10. Continue plavix and high-dose statin for cerebrovascular disease.

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the information as follows:

The patient is an 86-year-old female with a past medical history of occipital stroke, memory difficulties, and atrial fibrillation. She was admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of cough and was found to be hypotensive with a systolic blood pressure of 80s. She was initially treated with fluids, but her blood pressure remained low, and she required pressor support.

The patient has been diagnosed with septic shock, with an unclear etiology. She has been treated with vancomycin and meropenem for empiric coverage of sepsis, and azithromycin has been added for atypical pneumonia coverage. Her blood cultures are pending.

The patient has also been diagnosed with hypoxemia, with a requirement for oxygen therapy. She has mild interstitial edema on examination, but no signs of pulmonary embolism or hypercarbia on VBG. She has been treated with albuterol for expiratory wheezes.

The patient has a known iron deficiency anemia, with a baseline hematocrit of 30. Her hematocrit has dropped from 31.2 to 26.6, and she has been transfused with 1 unit of packed red blood cells.

The patient has been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation, with a heart rate in the 110s. She has been treated with digoxin, but will need to discontinue if her renal function worsens.

The patient has also been diagnosed with acute renal failure, which is likely prerenal in the setting of septic shock. Her urine output has improved, and she is being monitored for further changes.

The patient has a history of cerebrovascular disease, with a previous occipital stroke thought to be secondary to cardioembolic disease. She is being treated with plavix and high-dose statin.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock is likely to continue to be a concern, and she may require ongoing treatment with antibiotics and pressor support.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemia may worsen, and she may require more aggressive respiratory support, such as mechanical ventilation.
3. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen, and she may require dialysis.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation may worsen, and she may require more aggressive treatment with antiarrhythmic medications or cardioversion.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's cerebrovascular disease may worsen, and she may require more aggressive treatment with anticoagulation or other medications.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires ongoing monitoring and treatment to manage her various medical complications.

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, the patient is an 86-year-old female admitted with hypoxia, hypotension, fevers, and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) with complicated volume status.

The patient's condition has remained stable overnight, with a heart rate in the 70s-80s after being started on diltiazem. The patient's blood pressure remains low, and the patient is still requiring oxygen therapy. The patient's urine output has decreased, and the creatinine level has risen to 1.3.

The patient has a history of asthma and has been diagnosed with c diff positive, with blood cultures pending. The patient has also been experiencing agitation and has been treated with ativan with good response.

The patient has several potential medical complications that can arise, including:

1. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient's hypoxic respiratory distress, combined with the possibility of pulmonary edema and underlying obstructive disease, makes ARDS a potential complication.
2. Sepsis: The patient's c diff positive status and septic shock diagnosis increase the risk of developing sepsis.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine level has risen to 1.3, and the patient's urine output has decreased, making acute renal failure a potential complication.
4. Anemia: The patient's slightly below baseline hemoglobin level and decreased urine output increase the risk of developing anemia.
5. Mental Status Change/Acute Agitation: The patient's agitation and altered mental status increase the risk of developing a mental status change or acute agitation.
6. Pulmonary Embolism (PE): The patient's history of asthma and the possibility of underlying obstructive disease make PE a potential complication.
7. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's atrial fibrillation and rapid ventricular response increase the risk of developing cardiac arrest.

The patient's plan of care includes continuing atypical coverage, nebs, weaning O2, and rate control to encourage forward flow. The patient will also be monitored for cultures, and attempts will be made to obtain sputum cultures and viral swab. The patient's fluid status will be closely monitored, and the use of CvO2 sat will be guided by volume management.

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old female admitted to the ICU with hypoxia, hypotension, fevers, and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR) with complicated volume status. She has been treated with various medications, including lasix, morphine, and diltiazem, and has shown some improvement in her heart rate and blood pressure. However, she remains critically ill with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), shock, and acute renal failure.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. ARDS: The patient's ARDS is likely secondary to pulmonary edema and may be exacerbated by her underlying obstructive lung disease. She may require continued respiratory support and may need to be considered for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) if her condition does not improve.
2. Shock: The patient's shock is likely secondary to her underlying sepsis and may be exacerbated by her ARDS. She may require continued vasopressor support and may need to be considered for hemodynamic monitoring and optimization.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure is likely secondary to her prerenal azotemia and may be exacerbated by her underlying obstructive lung disease. She may require continued dialysis support and may need to be considered for renal replacement therapy.
4. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely secondary to her C. difficile infection and may be exacerbated by her underlying obstructive lung disease. She may require continued antibiotics and may need to be considered for additional antibiotics if her infection does not improve.
5. Mental Status Change/Acute Agitation: The patient's mental status change and acute agitation may be secondary to her underlying sepsis and may be exacerbated by her underlying obstructive lung disease. She may require continued sedation and may need to be considered for additional sedation if her agitation does not improve.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be secondary to her underlying chronic kidney disease and may be exacerbated by her acute renal failure. She may require continued transfusions and may need to be considered for additional transfusions if her anemia does not improve.
7. Pulmonary Embolism: The patient's pulmonary embolism may be secondary to her underlying obstructive lung disease and may be exacerbated by her ARDS. She may require continued anticoagulation and may need to be considered for additional anticoagulation if her embolism does not improve.
8. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest may be secondary to her underlying cardiac disease and may be exacerbated by her ARDS. She may require continued cardiac monitoring and may need to be considered for additional cardiac support if her cardiac arrest does not improve.

In conclusion, the patient is critically ill and requires continued close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential medical complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple medical complications. Here is a summary of the patient's condition:

* Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is 91/42 mmHg, which is low, indicating hypotension.
* Fevers: The patient's temperature is 37.1C (98.7F), which is elevated, suggesting a possible infection.
* Agitation: The patient is agitated, which may be related to their underlying medical condition or medication side effects.
* Respiratory Distress: The patient has hypoxic respiratory distress, likely secondary to pulmonary edema, with a possibility of ARDS-type picture evolving.
* Septic Shock: The patient has septic shock, with a positive C. diff culture, and is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.
* Acute Respiratory Acidosis: The patient has acute respiratory acidosis, possibly due to shallow breathing and increased dead space ventilation.
* Acute Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure, with a creatinine level of 1.3 mg/dL, and is at risk of prerenal azotemia or ATN.
* Anemia: The patient has anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 8.2 g/dL, and is being transfused with 1 unit of blood.
* Mental Status Change/Acute Agitation: The patient has acute agitation, which is being managed with medication, including ativan and zyprexa.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Progression of septic shock and multi-organ dysfunction
* Development of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Acute kidney injury or failure
* Cardiac arrhythmias or failure
* Sepsis-related mortality
* Infection-related complications, such as pneumonia or urinary tract infections
* Gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation
* Neurological complications, such as seizures or stroke

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continued treatment of septic shock with broad-spectrum antibiotics
* Monitoring of respiratory and cardiovascular status
* Management of acute respiratory acidosis with non-invasive ventilation
* Monitoring of renal function and management of acute renal failure
* Transfusion of blood products as needed
* Management of anemia with blood transfusions
* Management of mental status change and acute agitation with medication
* Monitoring of patient's overall condition and adjusting treatment plan as needed.

   86 year old female with a past medical history of occipital stroke with
   memory difficulties and atrial fibrillation who presents from home with

   80s sysotlic non-responsive to fluid challenge.

   bilateral diffuse crackles.  Patient with persistent oxygen requirement
   since her recent hospitalization despite no known primary lung disease.
   No evidence of pulmonary embolism on CTA.  No signs of hypercarbia on
   VBG.  Pulmonary edema likely due to cardiogenic causes as patient has
   moderate aortic stenosis.  Also on differential is PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) 9614**]
   lung disease, ARDS secondary to sepsis.
   - suspect cardiogenic cause- will aggressively diurese with lasix and
   diuril
   - sputum cx if possible
   - Echo to reassess valves
   - cards consult
   - non-invasive ventilation if cardiogenic pulmonary edema
   - nebulizers PRN
   Hypotension:  Improving although etiology unclear.  [**Name2 (NI) **] has been
   off pressors since 2 PM [**8-30**].  C. diff found to be positive, but does
   not explain CT chest findings of ground glass opacities.    Will
   recheck ScVO2 for fluid management.  Random cortisol of 24.6 argues
   against adrenal insufficiency.
   - d/c vancomycin, meropenem
   - continue azithromycin for atypical PNA coverage
   - follow blood cultures
   - CVP goal [**7-18**], manage IVF using central venous O2 sat
   - influenza negative
   - given the occasional [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) **] send for a sputum culture
   Anemia:  Known iron deficiency anemia with baseline hematocrit 30.  No
   active sites of bleeding.  Guaiac negative.
   - s/p 2 units of pRBCs yesterday to improve hypotension and anemia
   - trend hematocrit
   - continue iron supplements [**Hospital1 7**]
   Confusion:  Patient with waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 533**] mental status at home.
   Current exam consistent for delirium with primary aspect of
   disorientation with non-focal neurologic exam.  Patient with known
   occipital infarctions thought to be secondary to cardioembolic
   phenomenon.
   - continue home zyprexa and sertraline
   - Ativan PRN
   - monitor mental status
   - frequent orientation
   - optimize sleep wake cycle
   - limit medications that affect mental status as much as possible
   Atrial Fibrillation:  Rhythm currently in atrial fibrillation,
   controlled at 70s-90s on dilt.  No chest pain or shortness of breath.
   - continue digoxin, f/u digoxin levels in AM given RF
   - off metoprolol
   - restarted dilt drip after PO did not control HR
   Acute Renal Failure:  Creatinine trending up at 1.8 today.  Likely

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old female with a past medical history of occipital stroke, memory difficulties, and atrial fibrillation, who presents to the ICU with hypotension, respiratory distress, and acute kidney injury. She has been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation, acute renal failure, and diastolic heart failure, and is being treated with various medications and therapies. Her current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T: 36.6C, HR: 103 bpm, BP: 87/43 mmHg, RR: 28 breaths/min, SpO2: 96%
* Respiratory support: High-flow nasal cannula
* Hemodynamic monitoring: CVP: 12 mmHg, SvO2: 59-85%
* Renal function: Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL, UOP: 10-20 cc/hr
* Electrolyte imbalance: Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia
* Blood cultures: Positive for C. difficile
* Laboratory results: WBC: 13.6 x 10^9/L, Hct: 26.6%, Plt: 245 x 10^9/L, Cr: 1.8 mg/dL, Trop-T: 0.04 ng/mL

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's positive blood cultures for C. difficile and her current condition of septic shock increase her risk of developing sepsis.
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine level of 1.8 mg/dL and her UOP of 10-20 cc/hr suggest AKI, which can further compromise her kidney function.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation and her history of cardiogenic pulmonary edema increase her risk of developing other cardiac arrhythmias.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress and her requirement for high-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy increase her risk of developing respiratory failure.
5. Infection: The patient's positive blood cultures for C. difficile and her current condition of septic shock increase her risk of developing other infections.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's positive blood cultures for C. difficile and her current condition of septic shock increase her risk of developing gastrointestinal bleeding.
7. Thromboembolic events: The patient's history of cardiogenic pulmonary edema and her current condition of septic shock increase her risk of developing thromboembolic events.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential medical complications, it is recommended that she receive close monitoring and aggressive management of her sepsis, AKI, and cardiac arrhythmias.

   Assessment and Plan
   86 year old female with a past medical history of occipital stroke with
   memory difficulties and atrial fibrillation who presents from home with
   [**Month/Year (2) **] for one week found in the emergency room to be hypotensive to the
   80s sysotlic non-responsive to fluid challenge.
   Septic Shock:  Etiology unclear.  [**Name2 (NI) **] has been off pressors since 2
   PM [**8-30**].  C. diff found to be positive, but does not explain CT chest
   findings of ground glass opacities.    Will recheck ScVO2 today for
   fluid management.  Random cortisol of 24.6 argues against adrenal
   insufficiency.  At this time with hypotension, low grade fevers and
   tachycardia concern for sepsis although source is unclear.  History of
   [**Month/Year (2) **], rhinorrhea sore throat, and ground glass opacities suggesting of
   a viral upper respiratory tract infection for which influenza and PCP
   would be in the differential.   Other considerations include
   hypotension secondary to dehydration in the setting of viral illness
   and diuretic use.  Cardiogenic shock is unlikely given lack of cardiac
   symptoms and normal EKG.  Currently with mildly decreased urine ouput,
   normal lactate, mild acute renal failure and confusion but unresponsive
   to fluid challenge.
   - d/c vancomycin, meropenem
   - continue azithromycin for atypical PNA coverage
   - follow blood cultures
   - CVP goal [**7-18**], manage IVF using central venous O2 sat
   - f/u influenza swab
   - given the occasional [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) **] send for a sputum culture
   - will hold metoprolol and bumetanide
   Hypoxia:  Patient with persistent oxygen requirement since her recent
   hospitalization despite no known primary lung disease.  On presentation
   she was 91% on 2L and since fluid resuscitation has required 3-4L with
   saturations in the high 90s.  Evidence of mild interstial edema on exam
   but does not appear significant enough to account for oxygen
   requirement. No evidence of pulmonary embolism on CTA.  No signs of
   hypercarbia on VBG.  Pulmonary edema likely due to cardiogenic causes
   as patient has moderate aortic stenosis.  Also on differential is
   influenza, PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) 9614**] lung disease, ARDS secondary to sepsis.
   - holding home diuretics given hypotension
   - monitor for signs of volume overload
   - f/u influenza swab
   - outpatient pulmonary function tests
   - ABGs to assess oxygenation
   - nebulizers PRN
   Anemia:  Known iron deficiency anemia with baseline hematocrit 30.  Hct
   24.6 today.  No active sites of bleeding.  Guaiac negative.
   - transfuse 1 unit of pRBCs to improve hypotension and anemia
   - trend hematocrit
   - increase iron supplements to [**Hospital1 7**]
   Confusion:  Patient with waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 533**] mental status at home.
   Current exam consistent for delerium with primary aspect of
   disorientation with non-focal neurologic exam.  Patient with known
   occipital infarctions thought to be secondary to cardioembolic
   phenomenon.
   - continue home zyprexa and sertraline
   - monitor mental status
   - frequent orientation
   - optimize sleep wake cycle
   - limit medications that affect mental status as much as possible
   Atrial Fibrillation:  Rhythm currently in atrial fibrillation,
   controlled at 70s-90s on dilt and metoprolol.  No chest pain or
   shortness of breath.
   - continue digoxin, f/u digoxin levels this AM
   - discontinue metoprolol
   - transition to PO dilt TID
   Acute Renal Failure:  Creatining trending up at 1.3 today.  Likely
   prerenal in the setting of what appears to be septic shock, low UOP.
   ATN still remains in differential.
   - monitor urine ouput and creatinine
   - renally dose medications
   - urine lytes, UA
   - check urine sediment
   Diastolic Heart Failure: Patient diagnosed with acute on chronic
   diastolic heart failure during recent hospitalization although her
   response to diuretics was unclear and she does not have a history of
   hypotension.  Echocardiogram with preserved ejection fraction.  She is
   on bumetanide as an outpatient.
   - hold diuretics
   - hold metoprolol
   Right lower extremity edema:  No DVT shown on ultrasound
   Cerebrovascular Disease:  s/p occipital stroke in [**2200-6-9**] thought to
   be secondary to cardioembolic disease.
   - continue plavix
   - continue high dose statin
   - monitor neurologic exam
   FEN: IVF fluid management based on central venous O2 sats, replete
   electrolytes, regular diet
   Prophylaxis: Subutaneous heparin, famotidine
   Access: peripherals, RIJ

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is an 86-year-old female with a past medical history of occipital stroke, memory difficulties, and atrial fibrillation. She was admitted to the ICU with hypotension, unclear etiology, and septic shock.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.6C (97.9F)
* Heart rate: 103 bpm (normal range: 71-103 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 87/43 mmHg (normal range: 58-123/56-77 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 28 breaths per minute (normal range: 19-38 breaths per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 96% (normal range: 95-100%)

The patient has a history of C. difficile infection, which is currently positive, but does not explain the chest CT findings of ground glass opacities. The patient's labs show mild acute renal failure, anemia, and hypoxia.

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Septic shock with unclear etiology
* Atrial fibrillation
* Acute renal failure
* Anemia
* Hypoxia
* C. difficile infection
* Occipital stroke with memory difficulties
* Atrial fibrillation
* Diastolic heart failure
* Right lower extremity edema

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Discontinuing vancomycin and meropenem
* Continuing azithromycin for atypical pneumonia coverage
* Following blood cultures
* Managing IV fluids using central venous O2 saturation
* Following influenza swab
* Holding metoprolol and bumetanide
* Monitoring mental status
* Optimizing sleep-wake cycle
* Limiting medications that affect mental status
* Continuing digoxin and following digoxin levels
* Discontinuing metoprolol and transitioning to PO dilt TID
* Monitoring urine output and creatinine
* Renally dosing medications
* Checking urine sediment

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Sepsis
* Cardiogenic shock
* Pulmonary edema
* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Diastolic heart failure
* Right lower extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
* Cerebral edema
* Increased intracranial pressure
* Worsening of anemia
* Hypoxia
* Hypercapnia
* Hypoglycemia
* Electrolyte imbalances
* Renal failure

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, labs, and treatment response to prevent and manage these potential complications.

   primarily, presumed cardiogenic, but may be non-cardiogenic (ARDS).

   intially focus on cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

   echo to assess Aortic Valve (near critial on most recent) and LV
   function.  Cardiology to assess.

   including Flagyl.

   acceptable.  Monitor.

   AORTIC STENOSIS
 subcritical .  [**Month (only) 51**] be contributing to poor or
   compromised forward flow.  Repeat echo.
   C. DIFF ENTEROCOLITIS -- continue Flagyl.
   ANEMIA -- improved with PRBC transfusion.  Improved cardiac function as
   estimated by SvO2.
   CONFUSION --  attributed on last admission to occipital strokes, could
   be worse in the setting of acute illness
    ACUTE RENAL FAILURE -- evidence for prerenal azotemia, concern this
   represents poor or limited forward cardiac flow.   Would check cardiac
   echo to assess LV function.

   86 yo F with hypoxic respiratory distress and hypotension.

   edema.  Less likely atypical pneumonia.  Plan continue supplimental
   oxygen, consider non-invasive ventilation.
   DIFFUSE PULMONARY INFILTRATES -- attributed to pulmonary edema
   primarily, presumed cardiogenic, but may be non-cardiogenic (ARDS).
   Doubt pneumonia (atypical).  Plan continue to treat as outlined,
   intially focus on cardiogenic pulmonary edema.
   CHF -- concern for cardiac decompensation in setting of sepsis.  Check
   echo to assess Aortic Valve (near critial on most recent) and LV
   function.  Cardiology to assess.
   SEPSIS -- initial response to resussitation.  Continue antimicrobials,
   including Flagyl.

   acceptable.  Monitor.

 subcritical .  [**Month (only) 51**] be contributing to poor or
   compromised forward flow.  Repeat echo.
   C. DIFF ENTEROCOLITIS -- continue Flagyl.
   ANEMIA -- improved with PRBC transfusion.  Improved cardiac function as
   estimated by SvO2.
   CONFUSION --  attributed on last admission to occipital strokes, could
   be worse in the setting of acute illness

   represents poor or limited forward cardiac flow.   Would check cardiac

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old female admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with respiratory distress and hypotension. She has a history of atrial fibrillation, aortic stenosis, and chronic kidney disease. Her current condition is characterized by diffuse ground glass opacities and pulmonary edema, likely due to cardiogenic pulmonary edema. She is receiving supplemental oxygen and non-invasive ventilation, and is being treated for sepsis, anemia, and acute renal failure.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Progressive respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress and hypoxemia may worsen if not properly managed, leading to respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac decompensation: The patient's cardiogenic pulmonary edema and aortic stenosis increase the risk of cardiac decompensation, which could lead to cardiac arrest.
3. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may worsen if not properly managed, leading to multi-organ dysfunction and increased mortality.
4. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen if not properly managed, leading to chronic kidney disease and increased mortality.
5. Bleeding: The patient's anemia and coagulopathy may increase the risk of bleeding, particularly if she requires invasive procedures or has traumatic injuries.
6. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state and presence of indwelling devices (e.g., central venous catheter, urinary catheter) increase the risk of infection.
7. Confusion: The patient's confusion may worsen if not properly managed, leading to increased risk of falls, aspiration, and other complications.
8. Malnutrition: The patient's inability to eat and receive adequate nutrition may worsen if not properly managed, leading to malnutrition and decreased immune function.

Based on this information, it is essential to continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and adjusting her treatment plan as needed to prevent these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old female admitted to the ICU with respiratory distress, hypotension, and atrial fibrillation. She has a history of sepsis, cardiac decompensation, and acute renal failure. She is being treated for diffuse pulmonary infiltrates, cardiogenic pulmonary edema, and anemia. Her condition is unstable, and she is at risk for further complications.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient's diffuse pulmonary infiltrates and pulmonary edema increase her risk of developing ARDS, which can lead to respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac Complications: The patient's cardiac condition, including atrial fibrillation and possible cardiogenic pulmonary edema, increases her risk of cardiac complications, such as heart failure, arrhythmias, and cardiac arrest.
3. Sepsis-Induced Organ Dysfunction: The patient's sepsis increases her risk of developing sepsis-induced organ dysfunction, including acute kidney injury, liver dysfunction, and coagulopathy.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen her cardiac condition and increase her risk of cardiac complications.
5. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen her condition and increase her risk of death.
6. Infection: The patient's sepsis and pulmonary infiltrates increase her risk of developing further infections, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI).
7. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's sepsis and anemia may increase her risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting.
8. Neurological Complications: The patient's sepsis and anemia may increase her risk of neurological complications, such as seizures, stroke, and altered mental status.

Given the patient's unstable condition and multiple comorbidities, close monitoring and aggressive management are necessary to prevent and treat these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 86-year-old female who is critically ill and admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with respiratory distress. The patient's condition is complex and multifaceted, with several potential medical complications.

The patient's respiratory status is unstable, with hypoxic respiratory distress and diffuse ground glass opacities on chest imaging. The patient is receiving supplemental oxygen and is being considered for non-invasive ventilation. The diffuse pulmonary infiltrates are attributed to pulmonary edema, primarily cardiogenic, but may also be non-cardiogenic (ARDS).

The patient's cardiac status is also concerning, with atrial fibrillation and concern for cardiac decompensation in the setting of sepsis. The patient's blood pressure is controlled with Diltiazem infusion, and the patient's cardiac function is estimated to be improved with SvO2 monitoring.

The patient has a history of sepsis, with an initial response to resuscitation. The patient is receiving antimicrobials, including Flagyl, and has a central line and arterial line in place.

The patient's renal function is also a concern, with evidence of prerenal azotemia and concern for acute renal failure. The patient's cardiac echo is recommended to assess left ventricular function.

The patient's nutritional status is not well-documented, but the patient is receiving nutrition support. The patient's glycemic control is also not well-documented, but the patient is receiving insulin.

The patient has several potential medical complications, including:

1. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
2. Cardiac decompensation
3. Sepsis
4. Acute kidney injury (AKI)
5. Confusion
6. C. difficile enterocolitis
7. Anemia
8. Hypotension

The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), and the patient's disposition is ICU care. The patient has spent a total of 45 minutes in the ICU.

In summary, the patient is a critically ill 86-year-old female with multiple medical complications, including respiratory, cardiac, and renal dysfunction. The patient requires close monitoring and management of these complications to prevent further deterioration.

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old female with a past medical history of atrial fibrillation, occipital stroke, and memory difficulties. She was admitted to the ICU with hypotension and respiratory distress. The patient has been diagnosed with cardiogenic pulmonary edema, acute renal failure, and atrial fibrillation. She has been treated with diuretics, vasopressors, and antibiotics.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.3C (99.1F)
* Heart rate: 73 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 114/49 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 20 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 97%

The patient's physical examination is notable for bibasilar crackles, diffuse end-expiratory wheezes, and a soft, non-tender abdomen. Her extremities are warm and well-perfused, with 1+ pulses and 1+ edema in the right lower extremity.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 8.7 x 10^9/L
* Hematocrit: 28.6%
* Platelet count: 193 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 24 mg/dL
* Glucose: 115 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Transesophageal echocardiogram: Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy, normal left ventricular cavity size, and normal regional left ventricular wall motion. The aortic valve leaflets are moderately thickened, and there is moderate aortic stenosis. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened, and there is moderate functional mitral stenosis due to mitral annular calcification.
* Chest X-ray: Moderate cardiomegaly, pulmonary vascular congestion, and right pleural effusion.

Potential medical complications:

1. Pulmonary edema: The patient's pulmonary edema is likely caused by cardiogenic factors, including moderate aortic stenosis and mitral annular calcification.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure is likely caused by prerenal factors, including hypotension and low urine output.
3. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is likely caused by cardiogenic factors, including mitral annular calcification and moderate aortic stenosis.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely caused by iron deficiency anemia, which is a known complication of chronic kidney disease.
5. Confusion: The patient's confusion is likely caused by delirium, which is a common complication of acute illness and hospitalization.
6. Diastolic heart failure: The patient's diastolic heart failure is likely caused by mitral annular calcification and moderate aortic stenosis.
7. Right lower extremity edema: The patient's right lower extremity edema is likely caused by venous insufficiency and/or peripheral edema.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to aggressively diurese the patient with lasix drip to treat pulmonary edema and improve lung function.
2. Monitor the patient's urine output and creatinine levels to assess the effectiveness of diuresis and to detect any signs of acute kidney injury.
3. Continue to treat the patient's atrial fibrillation with diltiazem and monitor her heart rate and rhythm.
4. Consider starting the patient on anticoagulation therapy to prevent stroke and systemic embolism.
5. Monitor the patient's mental status and adjust her medications as necessary to optimize her cognitive function.
6. Consider referring the patient to a nutritionist to optimize her nutrition and to assess her need for tube feeding.
7. Monitor the patient's blood glucose levels and adjust her insulin therapy as necessary to maintain euglycemia.

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old female with a past medical history of occipital stroke, memory difficulties, and atrial fibrillation. She was admitted to the ICU with hypotension, respiratory distress, and acute renal failure. The patient has moderate aortic stenosis and severe mitral annular calcification, which may be contributing to her pulmonary edema. She has been diagnosed with acute on chronic diastolic heart failure and has been treated with diuresis and lasix drip. The patient's condition is complicated by sepsis, pneumonia, and possible PCP or ARDS.

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's moderate aortic stenosis and severe mitral annular calcification may be contributing to her cardiogenic shock.
2. Pulmonary edema: The patient's pulmonary edema is likely due to cardiogenic causes, but it may also be exacerbated by sepsis and pneumonia.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute renal failure is likely due to prerenal causes, but it may also be exacerbated by sepsis and pneumonia.
4. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely due to a combination of factors, including pneumonia, possible PCP, and ARDS.
5. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia is likely due to aspiration or secondary to sepsis.
6. PCP: The patient's possible PCP may be contributing to her respiratory distress and pulmonary edema.
7. ARDS: The patient's possible ARDS may be contributing to her respiratory distress and pulmonary edema.
8. Diabetic ketoacidosis: The patient's blood glucose levels are elevated, which may be contributing to her metabolic acidosis.
9. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte imbalance may be contributing to her cardiac arrhythmias and muscle weakness.
10. Infection: The patient's infection may be contributing to her sepsis and respiratory distress.

Recommendations:

1. Continue aggressive diuresis with lasix drip to treat pulmonary edema and improve lung function.
2. Monitor the patient's urine output and creatinine levels to assess the effectiveness of diuresis.
3. Consider adding antibiotics to treat possible PCP or ARDS.
4. Monitor the patient's blood glucose levels and consider administering insulin to manage hyperglycemia.
5. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and consider administering electrolyte supplements to manage electrolyte imbalance.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and consider intubating the patient if necessary.
7. Consider adding a vasopressor to manage the patient's hypotension.
8. Monitor the patient's mental status and consider administering sedatives or analgesics as necessary.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiovascular status and consider adding medications to manage cardiac arrhythmias.
10. Consider adding a pulmonary artery catheter to monitor the patient's pulmonary artery pressure and cardiac output.

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old female with a past medical history of occipital stroke, memory difficulties, and atrial fibrillation. She was admitted to the ICU with hypotension, respiratory distress, and acute renal failure. Her recent hospitalization was complicated by sepsis, and she has been diagnosed with acute on chronic diastolic heart failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: She is on high-flow oxygen and has diffuse bilateral crackles. Her ABG shows a pH of 7.40, PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 230, and a SpO2 of 97%.
* Cardiac: She has atrial fibrillation, moderate aortic stenosis, and severe mitral annular calcification. Her Echo shows mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy, normal left ventricular cavity size, and normal regional left ventricular wall motion.
* Renal: She has acute renal failure with a creatinine of 1.8 mg/dL and a urine output of 1,106 mL in the past 24 hours.
* Hematological: She has anemia with a baseline hematocrit of 30 and is receiving iron supplements.
* Neurological: She has a history of occipital stroke and is currently experiencing delirium.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient's moderate aortic stenosis and severe mitral annular calcification may lead to cardiogenic shock, especially if her heart failure worsens.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress and pulmonary edema may lead to respiratory failure if not managed appropriately.
3. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may worsen if not treated promptly and effectively.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen if not managed with aggressive diuresis and renal replacement therapy.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not managed with iron supplements and blood transfusions.
6. Delirium: The patient's delirium may worsen if not managed with aggressive treatment and close monitoring.
7. Cerebrovascular disease: The patient's history of occipital stroke may lead to further cerebrovascular events if not managed with anticoagulation therapy and close monitoring.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's assessment and plan are as follows:

* Respiratory: Continue high-flow oxygen, aggressive diuresis with lasix and diuril, and consider non-invasive ventilation if cardiogenic pulmonary edema persists.
* Cardiac: Continue digoxin, f/u digoxin levels, and consider restarting metoprolol if necessary. Hold bumetanide and metoprolol.
* Renal: Monitor urine output and creatinine, replete electrolytes, and consider renal replacement therapy if necessary.
* Hematological: Continue iron supplements and monitor hematocrit.
* Neurological: Continue delirium management with Ativan PRN, frequent orientation, and optimize sleep-wake cycle.
* Cerebrovascular disease: Continue plavix and high-dose statin, and monitor neurologic exam.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and aggressive management to prevent further complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   86 yo F with hypoxic respiratory distress and sepsis (C. diff).
   HYPOXEMIA -- attributed to diffuse ground glass opacities, pulmonary
   edema.  Less likely atypical pneumonia.  Plan continue supplimental
   oxygen, consider non-invasive ventilation.
   DIFFUSE PULMONARY INFILTRATES -- attributed to pulmonary edema
   primarily, presumed cardiogenic, (but may be component of
   non-cardiogenic, ARDS).  Doubt pneumonia (atypical).  Plan continue to
   treat as outlined, intially focus on cardiogenic pulmonary edema.
   CHF -- concern for cardiac decompensation in setting of sepsis.  Echo
   demonstrates perhaps worsening of Aortic stenosis (near critial on most
   recent) and LV function.  Cardiology to assess.
   SEPSIS -- Attributed to C. diff.  Responsed to resussitation.  Continue
   antimicrobials, including Flagyl.
   HYPOTENSION -- previously required levophed - remains off.  BP MAP
   acceptable.  Monitor.  Maintain MAP >60 mmHg.
   A-FIB -- good rate control on Diltiazem infusion. Tachycardia may have
   contributed to pulmonary edema.   Monitor.  Hope to transition to PO
   diltiazem.
   RENAL FAILURE -- acute, likely attributed to hypotensive insult in
   setting of sepsis.
   AORTIC STENOSIS
 subcritical .  [**Month (only) 51**] be contributing to poor or
   compromised forward flow.  Repeat echo.
   C. DIFF ENTEROCOLITIS -- continue Flagyl.
   ANEMIA -- improved with PRBC transfusion.  Improved cardiac function as
   estimated by SvO2.
   CONFUSION --  attributed on last admission to occipital strokes, could
   be worse in the setting of acute illness
    ACUTE RENAL FAILURE -- evidence for prerenal azotemia, concern this
   represents poor or limited forward cardiac flow.   Would check cardiac
   echo to assess LV function.

 initiate TF.
